comments.author: frank mclean

comments.text:
Thank you +bettyd1954 I liked the history of how the movie was made, it's 
unbelievable but true, the movie was made up by story telling as the movie 
was filming , the filming had to stop at times to wait for the next script 
to be written , the problem was disagreement over who was going to choose 
the story , there were too directors who wanted to make the story different 
from each other, heads rolled, it was amazing the film actually finished, 
some say it's about romeo and Juliet, racial prejudice, or about gangs, 
that's why this movie is so different :)

comments.author: Times Square NYC

comments.text:
Fifty years! It seems like 50 seconds. We who were there for the original 
stage production, and then the film, wondered if this greatest of American 
musicals might be forgotten as time moved on. It was so connected to a 
particular time and place. We need not have worried. Just saw it at the 
12,000-seat Muny Theatre in St. Louis and it was magnificent, and all the 
original orchestrations and choreography. The audience was besides itself 
with joy and at the end loudly sobbing.

comments.text:
I completely missed the swastica. It's an ancient human symbol (the Nazis 
turned it backwards), so ancient that Native Americans (First Nations, if 
you're Canadian) used it. Which probably means it's at least 12,000 years 
old. And will probably take another 12,000 years to wear off the negative 
connotation the fucking Nazis gave it (even if they got it backwards, the 
fucking assholes).

comments.author: Dame Blanche

comments.text:
You didn't answer my question and start accusing me of deliberately being 
insensitive to others. But its you who is being insensitive to me even when 
I have told you that Swastika is to Hindu what Cross is to Christians and 
Moon-Star is to Muslims. I can help an ignorant person but I can't help who 
is not willing to learn. And Swastika is used in India as a sign of 
auspiciousness. Every start of new business, every purchase of new car has 
this sign. And you r telling me not to use it..HELLO !
comments.author: mohit2k6

comments.text:
Acceptable to whom? To Europeans and Jews? See Indians were NOT a party to 
YOUR WARS so they simply have no obligations to bear the brunt of your bad 
deeds. Infact I don't even care what any Christian or Jews will think. I 
simply don't care for your narrow-mindedness. Hitler also made no mention 
of being a Hindu so why should Hindus suffer for his misdeeds. Anyway 
Hitler was a proud Christian and that is why he killed Jews. So stop the 
BS. I was talking to an arrogant and ignorant guy.
comments.author: mohit2k6

comments.text:
What was considered acceptable 10,000 years ago may no longer be 
acceptable, or you would be a slave. Hitler made no claims to being 
Christian. As long as you choose not to understand, you will be criticized. 
People who are deliberately insensitive to others don't deserve respect or 
consideration. This conversation, such as it is, is over.
comments.author: carrotjuse

comments.text: 2:17 I found Wally!!!
comments.author: dramaticafantastica

comments.text:
It's not "MAY BE TRUE", ITS REALLY TRUE ! I have sympathy for jews people 
but are you suggesting me that I should stop using MY RELIGIOUS SYMBOL, 
which we have have using for 10,000 years, just because a Christian nut-job 
like Hitler 70 years back, used a sign similar to the swastika to execute 
jews..? really.. Do you even know what this sign means to Hindus? If Hitler 
used CROSS SIGN , would Christians stop using cross? ANSWER ME FRANKLY !
comments.author: mohit2k6

comments.text:
It may be true that the swastika is an eastern religious symbol used in 
civilizations since Mediterranean Classical antiquity, the symbol in modern 
terms represents an unprecedented atrocity against an entire class of 
people based on nothing more than ignorance and prejudice. If you're 
offended by the ignorance of someone that it's a representation of a 
religious belief, imagine how Jews feel to see something that represents 
the systematic slaughter of several generations of their families.

comments.text:
If I had to guess, few to none of the people would have known it was from 
West Side Story. People are more familiar with the songs rather than the 
background music. It's a shame my favorite scene is the Prologue and I love 
it solely for the music and choreography. Leonard Bernstein was a master of 
his craft and the music proves it.
